awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity: Integrating Research, Mentoring, and Industry Collaborations to Improve STEM Recruitment and Retention
awd_abstract_narration:
The Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program (HSI Program) aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will also generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims. This project at the Phoenix College will advance the aims of the HSI Program by incorporating multi-disciplinary Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) into STEM curricula in colleges throughout the district. The program will develop CUREs for three targeted audiences. For non-science majors, it will develop a community-based CURE model designed to promote science literacy, positive attitudes toward science, and recruitment of students into STEM majors. For STEM majors, it will develop a CURE model designed to increase retention, transfer and degree completion of STEM majors.  For future STEM professionals, it will develop a workforce CURE model designed to improve workforce-related skills and interest in STEM careers. The program is expected to involve more than 3000 community college students. 

The specific goals of this project are to 1) promote increased interest in STEM disciplines, especially among students from groups that are underrepresented in STEM; 2) increase recruitment and retention of students in introductory STEM courses; 3) increase the number of students from two-year HSIs who transfer into STEM degree programs at four-year institutions; and 4) establish cross-sector partnerships with industry to improve workforce readiness and promote interest in STEM careers among two-year HSI students.  The project has constructed a comprehensive plan for developing, implementing, and assessing CUREs in introductory courses at two- and four-year institutions. The program will train and mentor community college faculty in the process of developing multidisciplinary CURE modules that address research questions relevant to university researchers, industry partners, and the local community. Identification of the unique barriers and best practices associated with the implementation of CUREs at two-year HSIs will be a useful resource for other two-year and four-year institutions, including two-year HSIs that want to increase the transfer success of students from two-year to four-year programs. Knowledge generated from this project will be shared within the Maricopa County Community College District system, and distributed to the larger educational community through local, regional, and national publications and conferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Students traditionally underrepresented in STEM often begin their academic training at community colleges. Therefore, community colleges must work to ensure that students are well-trained and competitive for STEM degree/career programs. Undergraduate research experiences are proven to increase engagement, retention, completion, and skill set development and better prepare graduates for STEM fields. Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) provide a larger population of students with the opportunity to engage in research, and are one strategy for increasing STEM workforce diversity and readiness. Although CUREs have traditionally targeted STEM majors in upper division courses, students who engage in research by their freshman or sophomore year are more likely to pursue STEM degrees or paths (NRC 2003).

To broaden and diversify the STEM degree pipeline, the STEM-CURE program: (1) created a curriculum template to aid in development of CUREs for STEM courses at community colleges; (2) developed, implemented, and assessed CUREs for students in non-STEM majors, STEM majors, and STEM workforce courses (Table 2); (3) provided training and mentoring for community college faculty during the design and implementation of the CURE projects (Figure 1); (4) established cross-sector partnerships with university, industry, government, and community partners to provide community college faculty with the capacity to conduct undergraduate research (Tables 1 and 2); (5) evaluated the impact of STEM-CURE projects on skill development and interest in STEM degree and career pathways among students traditionally underrepresented in STEM (Figures 1, 2 and 3); and (6) disseminated the STEM-CURE model for use by two-year institutions and the greater STEM education community (Figure 4).

Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts of the STEM-CURE project include:  creating a model for enhancing the lower division STEM curriculum at two-year institutions (Table 2), broadening participation of Hispanic students in STEM disciplines (Figure 4), and establishing cross-sector partnerships with university, industry, government and community organizations (Table 1). It also promoted professional exchanges between educators at two-year and four-year institutions and community partners for the advancement of quality STEM education. Students who participated in STEM-CUREs developed skills to better prepare them for STEM careers (Figure 2).  Furthermore, it provided a better understanding of how surveys should be adapted to address the unique needs of students at 2-year HSIs.  Specific broader impacts include: 

(1)   Faculty training, development, and support networks: The STEM-CURE project provided 92 community college faculty with training and mentoring networks needed to design and implement cross-disciplinary CUREs into existing STEM courses. It also connected faculty to several national CURE communities of practice, including Tiny Earth, SEA-PHAGES, CUREnet, CCURI and CUR. 

(2)  Expanding the STEM pipeline and increasing participation of underrepresented students: STEM-CUREs were offered in a total of 23 course sections at 8 of the 10 Hispanic-serving colleges that make up the Maricopa County Community College District (MCCCD). As a result, a total of 1,544 MCCCD students engaged in research relevant to industry, government agencies and community organizations.

(3)  Enhancing research capabilities through the development of university, industry and community partnerships: The STEM-CURE program established research collaborations (Table 1) with local business (4), ranging from farmers to engineering and water solution systems, government agencies (8), RI universities (6), industries (6) (engineering, computer science, and health services), academic agencies (2), community college districts (1), and non- profit organizations (6).  These partnerships enhanced the research capabilities of community college faculty and students and promoted the professional exchange of knowledge and expertise among two-year and four-year faculty and industry partners. Partners provided: training and mentorship for both students and faculty; student internships and jobs; resources and current topics of interest; and access to large databases for research purposes.  

(4)  Impact on STEM workforce and local community: Students participating in workforce development CUREs benefited from increased critical thinking and technical skills, an increased sense of self-efficacy and science identity, and a 1.5 times greater interest in pursuing STEM degree and career pathways (Figure 2). Collectively, these factors contribute to a better prepared and more culturally diverse workforce. This work led to our participation in statewide consortiums including the Arizona HSI Consortium and the Campus Cyberinfrastructure Regional Sun Corridor Network / Arizona Community College Research Expansion project ( NSF award # 1925632).

(5) Adapting assessment tools for measuring program outcomes:  After collecting and analyzing survey data from nearly 800 STEM-CURE students and conducting small focus group interviews, the STEM-CURE team recommends that surveys be developed or customized to address the unique needs of students at 2-year HSIs.  Many students at 2-year HSIs are first-generation and may speak English as a second language. Therefore, we recommend that bilingual surveys which limit the use of highly technical or academic language be used in conjunction with focus group interviews to better elucidate the impact of CUREs on sense of belonging, science identity and interest in pursuing STEM degrees and careers among students at Hispanic-serving institutions.


Last Modified: 01/23/2025
Modified by: Robin L Cotter
